docs.title: add(a, b)
docs.text:
Adds two integers together.

This function takes two integer values and returns their sum.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default a int

An integer to be added.

required b int

Another integer to be added.

required

Returns:

Type Description int

The sum of a and b.

Examples:

>>> add(1, 2)
3
Source code in src\main.py 
def add(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    """
    Adds two integers together.

    This function takes two integer values and returns their sum.

    Arguments:
        a: An integer to be added.
        b: Another integer to be added.

    Returns:
        The sum of `a` and `b`.

    Examples:
        >>> add(1, 2)
        3

    """
    return a + b

docs.title: greet(name)
docs.text:
Greets a person with the provided name.

This function takes a name string as an argument and returns a greeting string.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default name str

A string representing the person's name.

required

Returns:

Type Description str

A greeting string.

Examples:

>>> greet("Alice")
'Hello, Alice!'
Note

This function does not validate the name, it simply returns a greeting.

Source code in src\main.py 
def greet(name: str) -> str:
    """
    Greets a person with the provided name.

    This function takes a `name` string as an argument and returns a greeting string.

    Arguments:
        name: A string representing the person's name.

    Returns:
        A greeting string.

    Examples:
        >>> greet("Alice")
        'Hello, Alice!'

    Note:
        This function does not validate the name, it simply returns a greeting.

    """
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

docs.title: multiply(a, b)
docs.text:
Multiplies two integers.

Given two integers, this function returns their product.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default a int

An integer multiplier.

required b int

An integer multiplicand.

required

Returns:

Type Description int

The product of a and b.

Examples:

>>> multiply(6, 7)
42
Source code in src\main.py 
def multiply(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    """
    Multiplies two integers.

    Given two integers, this function returns their product.

    Arguments:
        a: An integer multiplier.
        b: An integer multiplicand.

    Returns:
        The product of `a` and `b`.

    Examples:
        >>> multiply(6, 7)
        42

    """
    return a * b
